void assignRandomValues ( ls_population *  pop  ) 

Initialises the population.

Goes through each coefficient structure and sets a random number to each coefficient.

Parameters:
pop The ls population to add random individuals to.

void chooseUniqueParents ( ls_population *  pop,
lsystem **  p1,
lsystem **  p2 
)

Returns two random but unique parents (not according to the uniform distribution).

Assumption: The population is already sorted.

The first parent returned is selected at random according to the following probability distribution:

IFSP(i)
pop->ifs_array[0]50%
pop->ifs_array[1]25%
.
.
.
pop->ifs_array[i]P(i-1)/2

The second parent returned is selected according to a similar probability distribution but the possible choices do not include the first (selected) parent.

Parameters:
pop The L-System population where the parents are chosen from (and children are placed).
p1 A pointer to the first chosen parent will be returned in this parameter.
p2 A pointer to the second chosen parent will be returned in this parameter.

Definition at line 191 of file ls_pop.c.

References ls_population::ls_array, ls_population::num_parents, and prng.

Referenced by generateChildren().

int compare ( lsystem **  ls1,
lsystem **  ls2 
)

Returns -1 if ls1 > ls2, 0 if they are equal, 1 otherwise.

The lsystem structures are compared by their fitness. This method will return

  • -1 if f(ls1) > f(ls2),
  • 0 if f(ls1) = f(ls2) and
  • 1 if f(ls1) < f(ls2).

Using this function in a sorting algorithm will result in the collection of lsystem structures sorted from largest fitness to least.

Parameters:
ls1 An lsystem structure.
ls2 Another lsystem structure.
Returns:
-1 if ls1 > ls2, 0 if they are equal, 1 otherwise.

const int  numparents,
const int  num_rules,
const int  rule_size 
)

Allocates memory for a new ls_population structure.

The structure is returned in the ls_population pointer given as a parameter.

Parameters:
pop A pointer to an ls_population structure.
numparents The number of parents in the population.
num_rules The number of rules the specified lsystem structure will hold.
rule_size The length or each rule (initially).

double getfitness ( ls_population *  pop,
int  i 
)

Returns the fitness of the specified L-System in the population (which is represented as an array).

Note: The array is sorted first before obtaining the fitness value.

Parameters:
pop An ls population.
i The position in the array of the ls whose fitness is wanted.
Returns:
The fitness of the ls in position i.

int  i,
char *  filename,
char *  lsname,
char *  comments 
)

Saves the specified L-System in the population (which is represented as an array) to file.

Note: The array is sorted first before saving to file.

Parameters:
pop An ls population.
i The position in the array of the ls to save to file.
filename The name of the file to write to.
lsname The name to assign to the L-System.
comments Any additional comments to be added to the created files.
